p: Frequently, close contact leads to human-to-human transmission (Chan et al. 2020). The transmission primarily occurs when an infected person sneezes and through the respiratory droplets produced, like in the spread of influenza and other respiratory pathogens (Chen et al. 2020; Read et al. 2020). These droplets can settle in the mouth or nasal mucosa and lungs of people with inhaled air (Li et al. 2020a). Currently, it remains unclear whether COVID-19 can infect a person by touching an infected surface or object and then touching their mouth, nose or possibly eyes (Chen et al. 2020; Phan 2020).
